original_title: Sri Lanka invites Japan to invest in dedicated investment zones, ports
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has invited Japan to invest in dedicated investment zones, power ports and highways, as well as a “green and digital economy” Foreign Minister Ali Sabry said after meeting visiting Japanese Foreign Minister Hayashi Yoshimasa.

Sri Lanka has also invited Japan to resume investment projects in the pipeline with the island’s economy showing signs of recovery, in discussion with President Wickremesinghe as well as himself, Sabry said Saturday.
Japan official development assistance projects are halted after the country defaulted on its sovereign debt last year.
Foreign Minister Hayashi said Japan sought Sri Lanka’s co-operation in maintaining a free and open Indo-Pacific.
“Sri Lanka is located at a strategic juncture along the sea lanes of the Indian Ocean and is an important partner is realizing a free and open Indo-Pacific,” Hayashi said.

“At today’s meeting, I explained about the new plan for FOIP that Prime Minister Kishida announced in March this year, and stated that Japan attaches importance to cooperation with the Indian Ocean Rim Association (IORA), which Sri Lanka will chair from October.”
Japan expected further progress on debt restructuring with transparent and comparable debt restructuring that involves all creditor countries, he said.

“The people of Japan can never forget about the emotionally touching speech delivered by former President Jayawardena at the San Francisco Peace Treaty Conference in 1951 after World War II which served as a stepping stone for Japan’s return to the international community,” Hayashi said.
“Since then, Japan has been working side by side with Sri Lanka. Japan is very eager to support Sri Lanka along the way in the future as well.”
